contextId.information: How they are not like that can be stated clearly. "The wicked are not prosperous" or "The wicked do  not prosper" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Here sitting represents ruling. What he sits on can be stated clearly. AT: "rules in the heavens" or "sits on his throne in heaven" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The person saying this is the king. This can be stated clearly. AT: "The king says 'I will announce a decree of Yahweh'"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: I will announce a decree of Yahweh

contextId.information: The relationship between "tremble" and "fear" and who people should fear can be stated clearly. AT: "Fear Yahweh so much that you tremble" or "Stand in awe of Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

What he remembers can be stated clearly. AT: "For the God who avenges bloodshed remembers those who were killed" or "For God remembers those who were killed and he punishes the killers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: For the God who avenges bloodshed remembers

contextId.information: It is implied that the oppressed people cried out to God. AT: "when oppressed people cried out to you, you listened to them tell you what they need" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: you have heard the needs of the oppressed

contextId.information: Here "faithful" means to do what God commands one to do. You can state this clearly. AT: "to those who faithfully obey your commandments" or "to those who faithfully do your covenant" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Here "trembling" shows that they were very afraid. This can be stated clearly in the translation. AT: "foreigners came shaking, showing that they were very afraid" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here the writer means that he will give thanks to Yahweh so that all people will hear of Yahweh's greatness. AT: "so all the nations will hear about it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The writer uses the word "For" to begin explaining why he is confused and asking God why he is not coming to help. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"he listened." It is implied that he responded when he heard their cry. AT: "he answered" or "he helped" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

This refers to the fellowship meal which occurs after the writer offers to God the sacrifices that he promised. He will invite those who were suffering to eat a part of the animal he sacrificed. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: The oppressed will eat and be satisfied

contextId.information: "Do not let those who hope in you be disgraced." Disgrace could come from being defeated by their enemies. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Do not let enemies defeat those who hope in you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: May no one who hopes in you be disgraced

contextId.information: It is implied that "do not understand" means they ignore or do not honor Yahweh's works. AT: "they do not regard with honor what Yahweh has done" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: they do not understand the deeds of Yahweh

contextId.information: The reason they open their mouths is to accuse the writer. AT: "They shout at me in order to accuse me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: They open their mouths wide against me

contextId.information: Here the watching implies observing the righteous in order to do them harm. AT: "waits in ambush for the righteous person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Warriors carried their swords in a sheath that hung from a belt around their waist. The sword would rest against their side. This phrase describes an action of someone preparing for battle. AT: "Prepare yourself for battle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Put your sword on your side

contextId.information: Clapping your hands is associated with celebration. AT: "Clap your hands in celebration" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

It is implied that what they have heard is the great things that God has done in the past. AT: "As we have heard about the great things that God has done" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
These people trust their wealth will keep them from having to suffer. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: those who trust in their wealth

contextId.information: To "sit and speak" against someone implies that this person deliberately thinks of bad things to say about someone. AT: "You always think of ways to speak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

What they might escape can be sued clearly. AT: "Do not let them escape your punishment for their iniquity" or "Do not let them escape when you punish them for the wicked things they do"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Do not let them escape doing iniquity

contextId.information: It can be stated clearly that the purpose of waking up is to sing praises to God. Waking up may be a metaphor for starting or preparing to do something.  The heart represents the psalmist or his emotions. AT: "Wake up, my honored heart, to sing praises to God" or "I will prepare my honored heart to sing praises to God"  or "I am honored to wake up and sing praises to God" or (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

Here "to remain before God" means to be in God's presence or to be with God. This can be stated clearly in the translation. AT: "God will be with him forever" or "God will be with the king forever" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: He will remain before God forever

contextId.information: David is speaking about himself. This can be stated clearly in the translation. AT: "I, the king of Israel," (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The implied information may be stated clearly. "taught me many things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Asaph is probably speaking of the time God brought Israel out of Egypt, divided the Sea of Reeds, led Israel through it on dry land, then drowned Pharaoh's army. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The soldiers probably also had arrows. AT: "had bows and arrows for weapons" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"Turn back to us" or "Come and help us again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The writer is asking God to defeat Israel's enemies as he has done in the past. (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Do to them ... for the earth

contextId.information: The writer is not acknowledging these other gods exist. He is referring to false gods that people from other nations worship. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
You can make explicit that "chosen one" refers to David. AT: "I made a promise to David, the one I chose" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: I have made a covenant with my chosen one

contextId.information: The word "Rahab" here refers to a monster of the sea. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
contextId.quote: You crushed Rahab as one who is killed

contextId.information: Here the word "worship" implies shouting and blowing horns. These were common acts of worship during Israelite festivals. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

The "stones" refer to the stones that were part of the city walls before they were destroyed. AT: "still love the stones that were formerly in the city walls" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
It may be helpful to state that it is food that is given. AT: "When you give food to them, they gather it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: When you give to them, they gather

contextId.information: This means that Yahweh does not look at them or pay attention to them. AT: "when you do not look upon them" or "when you ignore them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

When the Israelites left Egypt they took silver and gold with them. AT: "He brought the Isrealites out of Egypt with silver and gold in their possession" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: He brought the Israelites out with silver and gold

contextId.information: This refers to the Israelites' camp in the wilderness. AT: "In the camp in the wilderness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This refers to how oil soaks into bones when rubbed on the skin. AT: "like olive oil soaks into a person's bones when it is rubbed on his skin" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This means that he is weak and it is difficult for him to stand. AT: "I have difficulty standing" or "My body is weak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

Here David speaks of Yahweh extending the area that the king rules as holding out his scepter. AT: "Yahweh will extend the area over which you powerfully rule" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh will hold out the scepter of your strength

contextId.information: This means that he will not change what he has said. AT: "will not change his mind" or "will not change what he has said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

The king only stops briefly for a drink and then he continues the pursuit of his enemies. AT: "As he pursues his enemies, he will only stop to drink quickly from a brook" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: He will drink of the brook along the road

contextId.information: The idols do not have real mouths, eyes, ears, or noses. Rather, people made them with the likeness of mouths, eyes, ears, and noses. The writer is emphasizing that these idols are not really alive. You can make clear the implied information. AT: "People have given mouths to those idols" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

The idols do not have real hands, feet, or mouths. Rather, people made them with the likeness of hands, feet, and mouths. The writer is emphasizing that these idols are not really alive. You can make this implicit information clear. AT: "People have given hands to those idols" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

This is probably a reference to a drink offering, which was a sacrifice that involved pouring wine on the altar, and which the writer will offer in response to Yahweh saving him. The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. AT: "I will present a drink offering to Yahweh because he saved me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: I will raise the cup of salvation

contextId.information: "Open to me the gates through which the righteous people enter." This is a reference to the gates of the temple, and the writer is addressing the gatekeepers. The full meaning of this can be made clear. AT: "Open for me the temple gates" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: Open to me the gates of righteousness

contextId.information: The writer referred to himself as God's servant to show his humility. AT: "me, your servant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This is a request. AT: "please give me your unfailing love" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This is a reference to when the decrees, the Law, were given to Moses many years before. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

This means Yahweh is all he wants. Just as the Levites did not receive vast territories of land for the Lord was to be their portion so the writer claims Yahweh as the satisfier of his needs. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

The word "it" probably refers to where God's sacred chest was. The phrase "in Ephrathah" probably refers to where they were when they heard about it. This can be stated clearly. AT: "we who were in Ephrathah heard about where the sacred chest was" or "we in Ephrathah heard that the holy box was in Jaar" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: we heard about it in Ephrathah

contextId.information: This is a request for God to tell the psalmist about any sinful thoughts that he may have. AT: "Please search me" or "I beg you to search me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This means that just as God made the first human, Adam, from the soil, so will a person's body decay and become soil again when he dies. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
